Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as fb54610544f97b989b549d8fc94518e2d38c9467

EventService should be sending Event objects, not message objects.

?

Unless I'm missing something, in which case please link the appropriate part of the spec.

Agreed. I think it is an event object.
I changed it to use `EventServiceManager::getInstance().sendEvent()`

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/75791/comment/0164f161_4200e5f9/

As described in the previous reply to Gunnar's comment, I've changed to send the heartbeat only to the enabled subscriber.
Ok, that's a start, but how are we testing this if we had tests that passed, but produced the wrong type?  Can we get some level of test procedure documented?

I updated the commit message about tests to monitor heartbeat messages for 1 or multiple subscriber cases.

I think the heartbeat event message content may need to be updated again after dealing with Heartbeat event messaging - https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/75791/comment/56ff98be_d494bf8b/
Redfish event listener clearly isn't testing types.  Do we need to hand the output to another tool to do that?

The subscription needs a listener or subscriber (as https server) so that bmcweb sends a https invocation (e.g. HttpClient) to the listener.
I think we may need a something like test mock over HttpClient???

If it is not easy enough, can we consider the part separately??

I don't think we need a mock (although that would be great).  we need something that we can pump the schema to and verify it.  If no such tool exists....... I guess we'll go forward with what exists, but we really should be looking at this.

I submitted a commit - https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/75979 to fix `eventMatchesFilter()` to handle MessageIds which may have 5 parts like
- "MessageId": "TaskEvent.1.0.3.TaskStarted",
- "MessageId": "HeartbeatEvent.1.0.1.RedfishServiceFunctional",

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/75979 also adds a HeartbeatEvent test cases (which may address this test related points).
Those address the 3 vs 2 part version issue, not the fact that this was sending LogEntries initially, not events.
This version part issue seems being addressed by https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/76180
Done

I don't see any handling for PATCH if the user enables/disables heartbeat, the timer should be started/stopped appropriately, right?

Can you please test the patch case?

Yes, it has been tested.

This `scheduleNextHeartbeatIfNeeded` is called after PATCH - https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/75791/1/redfish-core/lib/event_service.hpp#L886.

This function cancels `hbTimer` first, and reschedule it if needed.
I'll redo the code so that `scheduleNextHeartbeat()` is called only if heartbeat is enabled.
Done. The patch is in the commit msg.
Done
Remove.  If the timer is running, there's no need to recheck this stuff.  If these change, code needs to appropriately start or stop the timer.

Currently, this function is invoked also from PATCH (which may be disabling heartbeat) and thus it checks it again.
However, I'm going to restructure the code.

This looks like it was copied from somewhere else?

Presumably this needs to return?

I think we can return if ec == aborted or operation_cancelled.
But the other cases, should we retry like `timer expired`?  (If not, the heartbeat may be stopped due to those errors without any notifications?)

> If not, the heartbeat may be stopped due to those errors without any notifications?

If the timer is returning errors, we don't know if it's valid anymore.  System level errors should not result in the timer restarting unless it's a known error and we handle it explicitly (like operation_aborted).

the remaining errrors should all stop the heartbeat.

Agreed.
I made it as CRITICAL and stopping the heartbeats.

This is going to cause last-event-id to increment, and the logic to be correct.  I think this needs to call eventservicemanager to send the message.

Do heartbeat messages need an ID?
I use Subscription's `eventSeqNum` as `EventId`, so that it will increment for each event

> so that it will increment for each event

Is this correct behavior?  I don't really know, because heartbeats are a per-subscription "event".  Is there something in the redfish spec that defines what should happen here?

DMTF schema specifies that Heartbeat is per EventDestination 

https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP2046_2024.3.pdf
```
6.42.2 URIs 
/redfish/v1/EventService/Subscriptions/{EventDestinationId}
- HeartbeatIntervalMinutes
- SendHeartbeat
```

Its heartbeat message is also defined as per-destination (e.g. subscription)

https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP2065_2024.1.pdf
````
2.6 HeartbeatEvent 1.0.1
2.6.1 RedfishServiceFunctional

 An event sent periodically upon request to indicates that the Redfish service is functional. • 
 This message shall indicate that the Redfish service is functional. 
 This message shall only be sent if specifically requested 
 by an event destination during the creation of a subscription using the property.
 ```
Right, so we shouldn't be assigning a global ID for them (which it looks like you've implemented).
As to follow https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/75791/comment/d9ae1599_9d15f02f/, it seems now addressed.
same here.  no need to check subscriptionTypeSSE if sendHeartbeat can never be enabled on SSE
Fixed

Okay, yeah Redfish created this message/registry just for this 
https://redfish.dmtf.org/registries/HeartbeatEvent.1.0.1.json

            "LongDescription": "This message shall indicate that the Redfish service is functional.  This message shall only be sent if specifically requested by an event destination during the creation of a subscription using the `SendHeartbeatMinutes` property.",

might be worth mentioning the message being used

DMTF message registry spec must be a typo `SendHeartbeatMinutes` and it should be `HeartbeatIntervalMinutes`.

I've created an issue - https://github.com/DMTF/Redfish/issues/6278

I'll also add the link as a reference to the commit message.
Cool. Mike already has a fix up. Good catch.

This follows the standard 5 retries?

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/463a0e3e880340a119bf986bab039d1afbe1a432/http/http_client.hpp#L101

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/463a0e3e880340a119bf986bab039d1afbe1a432/http/http_client.hpp#L441

And then, if "TerminateAfterRetries," it will delete the subscription ?

In fact, it is not correct to use `EventServiceManager::getInstance().sendEvent()` as it will send out the heartbeat to all subscribers (whether they enable heartbeat or not).

Heartbeat is per-destination as DMTF spec mentions - https://github.com/DMTF/Redfish/blob/d9e54fc8393d8930bd42e8b134741f5051a2680f/registries/HeartbeatEvent.1.0.1.json#L14
```
... This message shall only be sent if specifically requested by an event destination during the creation of a subscription...
```

This can also be verified by doing
- create 2 event listeners with 2 different destinations (e.g. port 8080, and port 8081)
- Patch sendheartbeat=true to only one subscriber.
- We expect the heartbeat is happening only for the subscriber that enables the heartbeat.

So, I've changed so that heartbeat is sent to only the specified subscriber.

--
Regarding "...And then, if "TerminateAfterRetries," it will delete the subscription ?",
yes, it will also delete the subscription if the heartbeat can't be sent after retries under "TerminateAfterRetries".  This will effectively achieve the goal to make sure the subscription to be kept alive only if the subscriber is reachable.

I submitted another patchset6 - https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/75791/6.

- patchset6 basically doing the same as patchset5 (i.e. send the heartbeat to only to the target event destination) - https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/75791/5.
- However, patchset6 reuses `EventServiceManager::getInstance().sendEvent()` like patchset4 (instead of creating another `sendHeartbeatEventToSubscriber()` function under `Subscription`).
Let's mark this point as resolved.
include span, string_view
Done
Why is a forward declaration required?  rearrange so the header can be included.

This has been changed to be a normal class member function as 
`void Subscription::sendHeartbeatEvent()' and placed it in subscription.cpp after breaking the header/cpp by https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/75235.

Please see https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/75791/7..12/redfish-core/src/subscription.cpp#108
This should automatically abort on destruction of the Subscription.  No need to explicitly cancel it.

Thanks for pointing out this.
Removed the part.
Please follow the pattern the other methods follow for declaring in the class

This part was done this way due to the order of the classes `Subscription` & `EventServiceManager` before.
After https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/75235, I've redone this as a normal member function of `Subscription`  -  https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/75791/7..12/redfish-core/src/subscription.cpp#108
As written this looks like it breaks event ids if a heartbeat is sent?

Yes, each heartbeat is treated like a new event?
Should we have a separate event id (e.g. for HeartbeatEventId)?

This architectural thought and testing.  Currently bmcweb treats all IDs as global to the system.  This patch is changing that such that some ids are now subscription specific.  What I suspect we need to do is come up with a mechanism where hearbeats are still assigned a system-wide ID, but are only sent to a single subscription, similar to if they had been filtered.

Would this be related to this?
 
```
curl -k -X GET https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/EventService/

  "RegistryPrefixes": [
    "Base",
    "OpenBMC",
    "TaskEvent"
  ],
  "ResourceTypes": [
    "IBMConfigFile",
    "Task"
  ],
```

And todos are
- add "HeartbeatEvent" for RegistryPrefixes 
-  add "Heartbeat" for ResourceTypes
- Deal with those additional prefixes and resourceTypes like "TaskEvent" or "Task'. e.g. sendEvent("Heartbeat") for heartbeat.

I'll play around more

> Would this be related to this?
>  
> ```
> curl -k -X GET https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/EventService/
> 
>   "RegistryPrefixes": [
>     "Base",
>     "OpenBMC",
>     "TaskEvent"
>   ],
>   "ResourceTypes": [
>     "IBMConfigFile",
>     "Task"
>   ],
> ```


No.  https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/a8770740ab793a16210ad2aa769d50d8110383ca/redfish-core/include/event_service_manager.hpp#L83

is what I'm talking about.

> 
> And todos are
> - add "HeartbeatEvent" for RegistryPrefixes
> -  add "Heartbeat" for ResourceTypes
> - Deal with those additional prefixes and resourceTypes like "TaskEvent" or "Task'. e.g. sendEvent("Heartbeat") for heartbeat.
> 
> I'll play around more

The current code is using `eventId` (event_service_manager.cpp#L83) but it is used as resourceType="" (so that it won't be filtered) as it will be sent by event_service_manager.

For the case of Task, it seems using "Task" - https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/a8770740ab793a16210ad2aa769d50d8110383ca/redfish-core/lib/task.hpp#L260C6-L261C62

What I meant is -
- isn't it to use something like "Heartbeat" as ResourceTypes so that it will be filtered like what's done like "Task".  (Or it may not be a matter?)

- Also "Origin"  which may need to specified as the original subscription URL?

Anyway, I'll keep play it around.

I modified  so that 
- Add "Heartbeat" resourceType for filtering
- OriginOfCondition as URL of subscription

```
curl -k -X GET https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/EventService/

  "RegistryPrefixes": [
    "Base",
    "OpenBMC",
    "TaskEvent",
    "HeartbeatEvent"
  ],
  "ResourceTypes": [
    "Task",
    "Heartbeat"
  ],
  
```

Heartbeat event message:

```
{
  "@odata.type": "#Event.v1_4_0.Event",
  "Events": [
    {
      "@odata.type": "#Message.v1_1_1.Message",
      "EventId": 1,
      "EventTimestamp": "2024-11-21T12:49:16+00:00",
      "MemberId": "0",
      "Message": "Redfish service is functional.",
      "MessageArgs": [],
      "MessageId": "HeartbeatEvent.1.0.1.RedfishServiceFunctional",
      "MessageSeverity": "OK",
      "OriginOfCondition": "/redfish/v1/EventService/Subscriptions/1521743607",
      "Resolution": "None."
    }
  ],
  "Id": 1,
  "Name": "Event Log"
}
```

In addition, add HeartbeatEvent to Registry 
`curl -k -X GET https://${bmc}/redfish/v1/Registries/HeartbeatEvent/HeartbeatEvent`.

I also submitted another commit - https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/75979

It is to make `eventMatchesFilter()` to handle MessageIds with Revision like
    - "MessageId": "TaskEvent.1.0.3.TaskStarted",
    - "MessageId": "HeartbeatEvent.1.0.1.RedfishServiceFunctional",
    
It also adds the tests for HeartbeatEvent message checking.

I modeled this after `error_messages.hpp` like

https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/d109e2b60f7bb367dc8115475c6cb86bca6e1914/redfish-core/src/error_messages.cpp#L152C1-L163C1

The similar ones are  `task_messages.hpp` or `resource_messages.hpp` like
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/d109e2b60f7bb367dc8115475c6cb86bca6e1914/redfish-core/include/task_messages.hpp#L29

Ug, that probably needs fixed to make those enums size_t so in this code we can just do to_underlying.

Ok, fine as is.  Please also be aware of the series that's generating these files.  Ideally we would generate this file as well.

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/75882
Done
This should only be called if the heartbeat values have been changed.
It is only called if sendHeartbeat is true (which the default is false), so only if the sendHeartbeat was added in the Post.
Yes, this is a part of POST and thus heartbeat is started only if heartbeat is enabled.
Won't this break the heartbeat cadence if this timer is less than the new set time?  Might not matter, but something to consider.

Right. The current code can causes the lapse of the heartbeat if a patch happens while the timer is being waited.

I'll do the schedule next heartbeat only if hbIntervalMinutes or sendHeartbeat as you suggested.

---
I still see another problem - in the case if hbInterval is changed.
- If a previous timer is started and waiting (e.g. says - 1/2 interval (t1) passed )
- hbInterval is changed (t2)

Then, the heartbeat will not occur until the next t2, and then total pause time will be 1/2 * t1 + t2 - which would be larger than both t1 or t2.
(Note, in the current code, the first heartbeat happens after the inteval from POST or PATCH).

Perhaps, should we start the heartbeat immediately after POST or PATCH?
Or, is it not an issue as the heartbeat interval should be measure from POST or PATCH?

> Then, the heartbeat will not occur until the next t2, and then total pause time will be 1/2 * t1 + t2 - which would be larger than both t1 or t2.

I think that is fine. The client changed the hbInterval interval. 
I would expect the heartbeats to start at the new value passed in. 

> Or, is it not an issue as the heartbeat interval should be measure from POST or PATCH?

We are getting down into the weeds but I think the heartbeat interval should be measured from the POST or PATCH (assuming they changed it on the PATCH and had it set in the POST)

Acknowledged.
Let's mark this point as resolved.

// schedule a heartbeat if sendHeartbeat was set to true 

would make this more clear
Done

This API existing is a bit odd, because subscriptionsMap is itself contained within EventServiceManager.  Passing it in as an argument implies that we're creating multiples of this, which we shouldn't (this is a singleton).
I make this back to the previous one, and add `sendHeartbeatEvent()` separately and made it like `sendTestEventLog()`
Should heartbeat events be filtered?
I separated `sendHeartbeatEvent()` from this. This will effectively bypass the filtering for heartbeat
here we're incrementing the eventId per subscriber.......  That seems odd.  Not anything to do with this patch, but I wonder if this needs rolled out of the loop.

I also think so.
For it, I created another commit - https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/76261
This should be private
Changed

DMTF schema specifies that Heartbeat is per EventDestination 

https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP2046_2024.3.pdf
```
6.42.2 URIs 
/redfish/v1/EventService/Subscriptions/{EventDestinationId}
- HeartbeatIntervalMinutes
- SendHeartbeat
```

Its heartbeat message is also defined as per-destination (e.g. subscription)

https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP2065_2024.1.pdf
````
2.6 HeartbeatEvent 1.0.1
2.6.1 RedfishServiceFunctional
...
 This message shall only be sent if specifically requested 
 by an event destination during the creation of a subscription using the property.
 ```
 
To implement this way, `hbTimer` is under `Subscription` (rather than `EventServiceManager`). So, I think it seems making sense to wrap it into `Subscription::heartbeatParametersChanged()`, and call it here like

```
    if (hbIntervalMinutes || sendHeartbeat)
    {
        subValue->heartbeatParametersChanged();
    }
    EventServiceManager::getInstance().updateSubscriptionData();
```
